column4: Original_notes
cotton, pepper, plantain, banana
50% maybe; 2 seasons — 1. Breadfruit and fish 2. Just land products. The second preferred; depends more on fishing than anything else
remove rocks and build up square of soil
Henry (1928: 37): old song referring to fencing of Ti; Cook ([?]: 51): protect young coconut palms from dogs – but may be fairly recent
around plots to carry off excess rain
irrigation ditches repaired
hard to die without any heirs since can adopt; reverts always to kin, never to chief however
support king and attendants
(+); morai system so old
Parkinson (1773: 23): whole island looks like one village
Hawkesworth ([?]: 96): 6,680 men furnished for war – divided into 8 districts; Adams (1901: 3): whole island estimated to have had at Wallis’ arrival 204,000
in front of altars
dance houses, temples
morais — also altars — bones of more important people buried there and marked with stones.
Pyramids are funeral places for nobles and altars — they give honor to the king according to their magnificence
dance houses
fortification in the mountains – retreat after losing war
used natural fortifications but also added stone walls
5-7 years before it needs thatching (Ellis 1831, vol. 1: 175); the posts sound fairly substantial (Handy 1932: 11), but rarely has walls (Handy 1932: 29)
Hawkesworth ([?]: 32) mentions numerous people but calls them single family – extended?
on Huahine the pillars sometimes painted but on Tahiti chief’s poles decorated with matting or braided cords
triangular pile of stones which formed a platform for the ceremonial archer ?
buildings -> structures?
stone pyramid platform with steps
Cook ([?]: 72) never saw the quarry but knew there was one
3 ½ ft by 2 ½ ft
the pyramid
pyramidal structure filled with round pebbles
no mortar
ancient ones sometimes built on flagstone terraces but the floor of the house unpaved, covered with sand
cut stone stairs – first step 6 ft high
Ellis (1831, vol. 2: 206): if the family left someone else would take the land; Henry (1928: 141): family morais were set up on all land owned and served as the only proof of ownership
large stones
Ellis (1831, vol. 2: 201): fruit trees marked by owner; Ellis (1831, vol. 1: 206): no registry
poor commoners acquire land by promising to go to war with chief and giving him % of produce
class of destitute become servants of nobles
chiefs own best fishing grounds and passages through reefs – charged rent; The sea all portioned out; over fruit trees
marriage feast – food and clothing collected and stored way before the actual ceremony
making the large canoes; idol makers; covering the ridge of the roof
Ellis (1831, vol. 1: 337): more feudal; Handy (1932: 59): public boat makers – professional
Important chiefs kept their own boat builder
tattooer
tattooer but not full-time
bearers of the King and Queen
cooks – servants or slaves employed  for that reason
Cook ([?]: 164): red feathers; Ellis (1831, vol. 1: 181): bark cloth
pearls
not really economically important – but frequent and organised
not finished goods traded out of Tahiti
to get chiefs to help first send them piece of pig – if accept then must gave aid in making fish net
inferior chiefs had to hire workmen
public works
king orders chiefs to supply him with goods or labor from their districts
important kept ship builders
canoebuilders
Cook ([?]: 225) – when chief blows conch all people must bring him food according to their wealth
viceroy in each district supervises tax collection

column4: Ellis (1831, vol. 3: 116) -; Ellis (1831, vol. 2: 127) + although often king requires additional goods
to entertain a visitor or have a feast
the chiefs hired superintendants to watch over the cultivation of their land – since they might have property scattered over the island; the king’s steward decides when necessary to obtain tribute
if a chief refuses to give produce to king he can be banished

Cook ([?]: 219) – when shortage of meat, chief forbids killing of hogs until they have bred themselves back into abundance; Williamson (1924, vol. 3: 328): wild bananas taboo in order to insure food in case of famine
social classes, royal family, chiefs, vassals, servants
royal lineage
2 go back accurately 30 generations so the other must go at 5
The Areois society of young men willing to kill their children – wandering entertainers
become friends by exchanging names and presents
husband pays father of the girl in proportion to the time he lives with her
Ellis (1831, vol. 1: 271): sounds very modern!; Henry (1928: 283): account of similar ceremony, perhaps authentic
the chiefs, the areois, the servants
the large landholders, some of these priests or chiefs and then[?] the royal lineage – the last could have children only among themselves
rich people never sacrificed because can give a pig. Poor people must give all their food to wandering nobility or be killed
babies designed for warriors have their heads flattened; royal family taller and whiter
Ellis (1831, vol. 1: 242): The Areois’ ranked and marked with tatoos; amount of cloth they wear wrapped around them  – and their goods; Adams (1901: 7): only chief could wear girdle of feathers
Adams (1901: 7): girdle of feathers; Handy (1930: 37): If a commoner put on the feathered robe of the chief he would contract leprosy
nobles more than commoners
superintendants of estates – would watch over tenants and servants
the other chiefs
The Areois could take as much food from gardens of a commoner as they desired
for special occasions – arrival of distinguished visitor etc. – held games, wrestling
different terms and forms of address for the upper class
The chiefs buried in sacred place and areois buried nearby
all bodies of nobles preserved; special houses – but simple
Hawkesworth ([?]: 44): cooking; Williamson (1924, vol. 2: 392) says slaves always cultivated chief’s land and criticises others for mixing up the terms for servant and slave
nation, 8 district, 4 divisions
200,000 – may have been more (Ellis 1831, vol. 1: 101); 6,780 fighting men could be furnished in Cook’s time (Cook [?]: 78)
King moved from estate to estate or wife to wife
able to banish or sacrifice but did not have much power unless majority of chiefs supported him
district chiefs
talking chiefs [underlined]
chiefs appoint their heralds
King has a viceroy in each district to receive his orders and make sure tribute is collected
King sends his messenger to every district. Each district chief then sends out his messenger to inform the people
Ellis (1831, vol. 1: 52): palm leaf = symbol of authority and sent by chief to his dependants; Ellis (1831, vol. 3: 122): “cocoa-nut” leaf sent with the messenger
dances, feasts, performances of the Areois
bestows high rank and property on successful warriors
can be banished for an offense and a new chief appointed

acting as religious official receives request
get food

kneel and embrace his legs
tribute of allegiance at coronation
child of a king or high chief is initiated into the ranks of the gods

inside the morai compound – his bones cleaned and buried, his skull wrapped in cloth and sealed in special box
embalmed
His skull kept by the altar and honored
chief’s house sometimes 397 ft+ long – most houses others under 100 ft. - this[?] enclosed in compound
chief has a house in each district

a number of attendants acting as bodyguards
his house very large, – keeps large bales of cloth – very valuable

can be either – usually fight

Ellis (1831, vol. 2: 125) don’t consider evidence simply convict; Williamson (1924, vol. 3: 16,18) says witnesses seldom called, so occasionally had real court?; Williamson (1924, vol. 3: 17) argues vs.
Ellis (1831, vol. 3: 121): district, national if brought up before the chiefs; Corney (1914: 264): special heralds also serve as judges in absence of chief
Cook ([?]: 226): victims do the punishing according to the laws; Ellis (1831, vol. 3: 123) says this explicitly; Cook ([?]: 226): certain crimes only important enough to bring before a chief

if criticise government
if a thief detected, his victims go to his house and take everything of value. He cannot object
beating

if a man condemned to be sacrificed he may offer hogs in his place

jealousy of one kingdom against another – seeking “self-aggrandisement”
a special human sacrifice seen as declaration of war
father of the chief; chief warrior under king
the skilled warriors follow the chief and are the first in battle

advanced guard, second rank, shoulder, fourth line and last division including wives

slingers and spearmen and orators
army followed by wives and baggage

form lines and as the first line tires the second line takes its place – exceptions

Cook ([?]: 222) – if continent for 3 months before death go straight to heaven – otherwise must be “eaten by god” – but all people go to the same place. Cook ([?]: 223) – drowned people stay in the sea – the stones etc. also go their heaven
ocean water sprinkled on the dead

to insure the gods aid in the future battle
